snippet: A law makes it easier for airports to replace federal screeners with private contractors, and several airports, after years of complaints, are lining up for the change.
abstract: New law makes it easier for airports to replace Transportation Security Administration screeners with private contractors; 16 major airports already use private screeners, and others, after years of passenger complaints, are lining up to make the change; law passed after a committee report found that taxpayers would save nearly a billion dollars over five years if the top airports made the switch.
lead_paragraph: A law makes it easier for airports to replace federal screeners with private contractors, and several airports, after years of complaints, are lining up for the change.

headline.seo: Airports, With New Law, Are Freer to Split From T.S.A.
headline.main: New Law Clears the Way for Airports to Drop T.S.A. Screeners
headline.print_headline: New Law Clears the Way for Airports to Drop T.S.A. Screeners
